Introduction

DNA is a double-stranded molecule made of paired nucleotide bases: adenine (A), thymine (T), guanine (G), and cytosine (C).  DNA is continuously damaged by environmental radiation, chemical agents, and endogenous reactive oxygen species from normal metabolism.  Unrepaired damage can be passed on during replication, becoming a mutation (permanent change in the nucleotide sequence).  Cells rely on multiple DNA repair pathways to correct damage before it becomes fixed as a mutation.  Inherited defects in these pathways are responsible for numerous cancer syndromes.

Types of DNA damage



DNA damage can range from subtle base modifications and single strand breaks (SSBs) to severe double strand breaks (DSBs).  In this section, damage is listed from relatively minor to more severe.

Base mismatch



Normal DNA base pairing is G:C and A:T.  However, during DNA replication, an incorrect nucleotide is inserted for approximately 1 in every 10 million bases copied, resulting in a mismatched pair (eg, G:T, A:C).  Most mismatches are corrected in real time by the proofreading function of DNA polymerase (

figure 1
).  However, a very small percentage escape proofreading and subsequent repair processes, leading to a mutation that is passed on to daughter cells.



In addition to the accidental mismatches above, incorrect base pairing also occurs when the template base has preexisting damage or modification (discussed next).  Such altered bases pair incorrectly in a way that evades DNA polymerase proofreading and are highly likely to become permanent mutations if not corrected prior to replication.

Base modification



A low level of damage to DNA bases always occurs due to spontaneous hydrolysis, normal cellular metabolism (eg, reactive oxygen species), and environmental exposures (eg, ultraviolet [UV] radiation).  There are 4 principal types of base damage:



  • A base can become oxidized (due to reactive oxygen species from normal metabolism) and mispair with the wrong partner base during DNA replication.  For example, guanine can be oxidized to 8-oxoguanine, which mispairs with adenine instead of cytosine.
  • A base can become alkylated (eg, due to environmental carcinogens) and mispair with the wrong base during DNA replication.  For example, guanine can be alkylated to O6-methylguanine, which mispairs with thymine instead of cytosine.
  • Cytosine can be deaminated (eg, due to spontaneous hydrolysis), which converts it to uracil.
  • An abasic (AP) site can form when the base is lost due to spontaneous hydrolysis, leaving behind an empty space in the DNA backbone.  This apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) site is mutagenic because it lacks base-pairing information, leading to random incorporation of A, T, G, or C during replication.

Single strand break



In addition to damage affecting the bases, the DNA backbone itself can also be broken by oxidative stress, ionizing radiation, or certain drugs (eg, topoisomerase I inhibitors).  If only one strand is affected, the lesion is referred to as an SSB.  Although the DNA is still held intact by the opposite strand, SSBs must be repaired quickly or they risk converting to much more serious DSBs during replication.  Repair is not as simple as sealing the nick because most SSBs have "dirty ends" (eg, dangling phosphate or hydroxyl groups) that DNA ligase cannot join.  Specialized end-processing enzymes are needed (eg, to trim back the termini), after which DNA polymerase and ligase restore the sequence using the complementary strand as a template.

Double strand break



If both sides of the DNA backbone are cleaved at the same location, a DSB is formed.  DSBs are among the most dangerous forms of DNA damage because the chromosome becomes discontinuous, often leading to rearrangements and deletions.  Because the complementary strand is also damaged, it is no longer available to guide repair.

Helix-distorting lesions



DNA has a helical structure because of its double stranded nature.  Helix-distorting lesions severely kink or lock DNA.  They include the following:



  • Intrastrand crosslinks are covalent bonds formed between adjacent bases on the same DNA strand, most often G-G or G-A.  They are typically induced by platinum chemotherapy (eg, cisplatin).  These crosslinks introduce a local bend in the helix.

    • Thymine dimers are a special case of intrastrand crosslink formed by covalent bonding of adjacent thymines.  They are exclusively induced by UV-B radiation.  The T-T dimer introduces a sharp kink in the helix.
  • Interstrand crosslinks are covalent bonds formed between complementary bases on opposite DNA strands, gluing the double helix shut.


These lesions interfere with DNA replication and transcription because the normal polymerases are unable to traverse them due to steric hindrance.  To overcome this, cells use specialized translesion polymerases that bind DNA more loosely; this allows for successful replication but is more error prone.  As a result, helix-distorting lesions can be mutagenic.

Single strand repair mechanisms



Single stranded lesions include:



  • Base modifications.
  • SSBs.
  • Intrastrand crosslinks and thymine (T-T) dimers.


For these lesions, the complementary strand is unaffected and can be used as a template for repair.

Base excision repair



Base excision repair (BER) is a process that corrects small, nonâ€“helix-distorting lesions such as oxidized bases, alkylated bases, deaminated cytosine, and AP sites.  The damaged base is simply removed and replaced (

figure 2
).  Briefly, a DNA glycosylase recognizes and excises the damaged base, leaving an AP site.  An AP endonuclease cleaves the DNA backbone at the AP site.  Then, DNA polymerase beta inserts the correct nucleotide.  Finally, DNA ligase seals the nick.



MUTYH-associated polyposis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the activity of DNA glycosylase (first step of the BER pathway).  Affected patients develop hundreds of colorectal adenomas and have an increased risk of colorectal cancer.  The phenotype is relatively milder compared to other colorectal cancer syndromes (such as mismatch repair [MMR] defects or familial adenomatous polyposis) because the underlying type of damage is less severe.

Nucleotide excision repair



Nucleotide excision repair (NER) removes intrastrand crosslinks (eg, T-T dimers from UV-B radiation) and other single strand bulky adducts.  In NER, DNA damage is recognized by detecting distortions in the DNA helix throughout the genome (or by sensing stalled transcription machinery at active genes).  The entire nucleotide (base + backbone) must be removed and replaced (

figure 3
).  Briefly, a dual incision is created by endonucleases (XPA, XPG).  The damaged segment is removed.  Next, DNA polymerase delta resynthesizes DNA to fill the gap, and DNA ligase seals the nicks.



Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in NER genes (XPA, XPG), leading to extreme UV sensitivity and early-onset skin cancers (eg, multiple squamous cell carcinomas in childhood).

Mismatch repair



MMR corrects base mismatches that escape proofreading during replication.  The complementary strand is used to restore the correct sequence (

figure 4
).  Briefly, the mismatch is recognized by specialized complexes (eg, MSH2-MSH6).  Next, endonucleases (eg, MLH-PMS2) are directed to the replicating (new) strand to remove the mispaired base.  Finally, as with NER, DNA polymerase delta resynthesizes DNA to fill the gap, and DNA ligase seals the nicks.



Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC, or Lynch syndrome) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in MMR genes (eg, MSH2, MLH1, PMS2).  Patients have a markedly elevated lifetime colorectal cancer risk (eg, 50% by age 50) and are also predisposed to gastric, ovarian, endometrial, and several other malignancies.  Adenomatous polyps are paradoxically few (unlike with BER), likely because the extensive genomic damage with MMR enables rapid progression directly to carcinoma.

Double strand repair mechanisms



DSBs can be repaired by nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous recombination (HR) (

figure 5
).

Nonhomologous end joining



NHEJ directly ligates the broken DNA ends back together.  A template is not required.  Briefly, specific protein complexes (eg, Artemis) gather the 2 ends and bring them in close proximity for DNA ligase to seal the break.  In the process, nucleotides may be lost or added, making NHEJ a relatively error-prone method.  As a result, small insertions or deletions can be produced at the repair site.



Although less accurate, NHEJ functions in all phases of the cell cycle because it does not require a homologous sister chromatid (only available after DNA replication in late S phase and G2).



Some forms of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) are caused by defects in NHEJ genes (eg, Artemis, RAG1/2).  NHEJ is essential for repairing the DSBs intentionally generated during V(D)J recombination in developing T and B lymphocytes, which is required for survival as well as T-cell receptor and B-cell receptor diversity.  Failure of this pathway leads to complete absence of T and B cells in the peripheral blood.

Homologous recombination



HR repairs DSBs with greater accuracy than NHEJ because it uses an undamaged sister chromatid as a template.  Therefore, it is restricted to late S and G2 phases of the cell cycle, after DNA replication has occurred.  The process begins with invasion of the broken strand into the intact homologous sister chromatid (mediated by BRCA1/2 and RAD51).  DNA polymerase then extends the invading strand using the sister sequence as a template.



Although more accurate, one disadvantage of HR is the potential for loss of heterozygosity (LOH).  HR can copy a pathogenic allele from the sister template, converting an otherwise recessive defect into a homozygous one.  LOH is a major mechanism of tumor suppressor gene inactivation, serving as the "second hit" in cancer development.  (Note:  Second hits can also arise independently through random mutations, even without LOH.)



Mutations in HR genes (eg, BRCA1, BRCA2) force the cell to rely solely on NHEJ, which is more error prone.  Patients have a markedly elevated risk of breast, ovarian, pancreatic, and other malignancies.

DNA damage response



The 5 primary repair pathways (BER, NER, MMR, HR, and NHEJ) are centrally regulated by a common DNA damage response (DDR).



The DDR halts the cell cycle so the machinery described above has time to fix errors.  Specialized protein complexes (eg, ATM) continuously monitor DNA integrity.  When they encounter damage, they phosphorylate downstream cell cycle checkpoint kinases to temporarily arrest the cell cycle.  They also activate proteins from the relevant pathway to begin repair.

Successful repair



Once the lesion is corrected, the cell cycle checkpoints are unblocked, and the cell is free to replicate its DNA or to divide.

Failed repair, cell eliminated



If damage is irreparable (eg, extensive DSBs), persistent DDR signaling can trigger apoptosis via p53, which is encoded by the TP53 gene.  Cells can also enter senescence, a permanent state of cell cycle arrest in which they remain metabolically active but no longer divide.

Failed repair, cell survives



Defects in DDR components (eg, p53, ATM) compromise all DNA repair pathways, allowing cells to continue surviving despite highly mutagenic DNA damage:



  • Defects in p53 lead to Li-Fraumeni syndrome, characterized by early-onset of often-concurrent malignancies in multiple tissues (eg, sarcomas, breast cancer, glioblastoma, leukemia).
  • Defects in ATM lead to ataxia-telangiectasia, characterized by progressive cerebellar degeneration, telangiectasias, immunodeficiency, extreme radiosensitivity, and high risk of lymphoma and breast cancer.

Summary



DNA is constantly damaged by replication errors, normal oxidative stress, and environmental exposures.  If not repaired prior to replication, these lesions can become permanent mutations.  DNA damage ranges from single base modifications to large helix-distorting lesions.  Five major repair pathways are available (

Mechanisms of DNA damage and repair
).  Base excision repair, nucleotide exclusion repair, and mismatch repair correct single strand defects, such as base modifications (eg, oxidation), mismatches, and intrastrand crosslinks (eg, T-T dimers), using the intact complementary strand as a template.  Nonhomologous end joining and homologous recombination correct double strand breaks.  Defects in each of these 5 pathways are associated with specific hereditary cancer syndromes (eg, loss of NER results in xeroderma pigmentosum).  Upstream failure of the DNA damage response itself (eg, ATM or TP53 mutations) compromises multiple repair processes and predisposes to cancer.
